in 1984 I worked for a company that made monoclonal antibody tests to detect antibiotic contamination in cow's milk. When a cow is treated with penicillin it appears in the milk for a period afterward. The FDA says you can't sell that milk commercially because some people (like me) are allergic to penicillin and could have a random bad reaction to a glass of milk. The company coated micron-sized spheres of latex with antibodies specific to penicillin and then mixed it with a sample of the milk. If there was the drug present in the milk the latex spheres would clump together in a process called agglutination, causing the sample to go from cloudy to clear with white clumps. The same process is used these days for pregnancy tests and rapid blood type testing. The process is quite versatile; you can coat the latex spheres with antibodies specific for practically any protein.

Here's a video I found illustrating how latex agglutination works: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oXL1rH11MTg

I don't think there are "billions of unique antibodies" in our body. There are only 5 types of antibodies found in our body currently, IgG, IgM, IgA, IgD, and IgE. Of course, we may find more types of antibodies in the future, but stating billions rn is just overly exaggerated. However, the content is really good and thank you for spreading knowledge.
